catalog.title: Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan
catalog.help:
Mathmet quality assurance tools (QAT) plans support the documentation of the people, procedures and activities performed to fulfil predefined quality objectives during the development and maintenance of a specific dataset or meaningful group of datasets, within the metrology community and wider scientific domains, in which quality and trustworthiness are essential. Based on version 19 of PDF template.
A completed data quality assurance plan facilitates the auditing of datasets, particularly with respect to the ISO 8000 series of standards.

page.title: Introduction
page.help:
The following questionnaire helps completing a Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan (DQP), which supports the documentation of the people, procedures and activities performed to fulfil predefined quality objectives during the development and maintenance of a specific dataset or meaningful group of datasets, within the metrology community and wider scientific domains, in which quality and trustworthiness are essential. A completed data quality assurance plan facilitates the auditing of datasets, particularly with respect to the ISO 8000 [1] series of standards. Further details of the approach taken in this plan are provided in the corresponding publication by Mathmet. Describe how non-conformities are identified and documented. Internal reporting and customer reporting could have different channels. For example, the development team can set up a procedure to assign priority levels to non-conformities. ISO 8000 standards characterise data quality according to its consistency with its format (syntactic quality), its meaning (semantic quality), and its usefulness (pragmatic quality).

Glossary

Term Definition Source
Audit Systematic, independent, and documented process for obtaining objective evidence and evaluating it objectively to determine the extent to which the audit criteria are fulfilled. ISO 9000:2015
Business impact analysis Process of analysing the impact over time of a disruption on the organization. ISO 22300:2021
Customer Person or organization that could or does receive a product or a service that is intended for or required by this person or organization. A customer can be internal or external to the organization. ISO 9000:2015
Data Reinterpretable representation of information in a formalized manner suitable for communication, interpretation, or processing. ISO 8000-2:2020
Data administratorPerson who controls and coordinates the work of data technicians by defining criteria needed to maintain data quality, by designing data schemata, and by analysing the causes of errors to prevent their recurrence.ISO 8000-2:2020
Data dictionary Collection of data dictionary entries that allows lookup by entity identifier. ISO 8000-2:2020
Data Integrity Level (DIL)A risk assessment metric that accounts for complexity and criticality levels. own definition
Data life cycle All stages in the process of data usage from initial establishment to its discontinuation. ISO 21710:2020
Data managerPerson who establishes plans for data quality improvement in an organization, grants data administrators the authority to trace and correct data over the information systems or organization, and maintains data consistency in individual information systems through the organization-wide data architecture.ISO 8000-2:2020
Data processingSystematic performance of operations upon data. Examples: Arithmetic or logic operations upon data, merging or sorting of data, assembling or compiling of programs, or operations on text, such as editing, sorting, merging, storing, retrieving, displaying, or printing.ISO 2382:2015
Data quality Degree to which a set of inherent characteristics of data fulfils requirements. ISO 8000-2:2020
Data quality management Coordinated activities to direct and control an organization with regard to data quality. ISO 8000-2:2020
Data set (or dataset) Logically meaningful grouping of data. ISO 8000-2:2020
Data specification Set of requirements covering the characteristics of data being fit for one or more particular purposes. ISO 8000-2:2020
Data steward Person or organization delegated the responsibility for managing a specific set of data resources. ISO 8000-2:2020
Data technician Person who creates, reads, modifies, and deletes data in accordance with the guidelines for data quality management, and measures data quality and corrects data errors found as a result of measuring data quality. ISO 8000-2:2020
Management systemA management system is a set of interrelated or interacting elements of an organization to establish:
  • policies, intentions and direction of an organization as formally expressed by its top management;
  • objectives, results to be achieved;
  • processes, sets of interrelated or interacting activities that use inputs to deliver an intended result, to achieve those objectives.
ISO 9000:2015
Measurement uncertainty Parameter, associated with the result of a measurement, that characterizes the dispersion of the values that could reasonably be attributed to the measurand. JCGM 100:2008
Non-conformity Non-fulfillment of a requirement. ISO 33020:2019
Quality The degree to which a set of inherent characteristics of an object fulfils requirements. ISO 9000:2015
Quality control Part of quality management focused on fulfilling quality requirements. ISO 9000:2015
Quality management system realization Process of establishing, documenting, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving a quality management system. ISO 9000:2015
Quality planning Part of quality management focused on setting quality objectives and specifying necessary operational processes, and related resources to achieve the quality objectives. ISO 9000:2015
Quality requirement Need or expectation that is stated, generally implied or obligatory, related to data. ISO 9000:2015
Repeatability condition of measurementCondition of measurement, out of a set of conditions that includes the same measurement procedure, same operators, same measuring system, same operating conditions and same location, and replicate measurements on the same or similar objects over a short period of time.JCGM 200:2012
Reproducibility condition of measurementCondition of measurement, out of a set of conditions that includes different locations, operators, measuring systems, and replicate measurements on the same or similar objects. JCGM 200:2012
Risk analysis Systematic use of available information to identify hazards and to estimate the risk. ISO 51:2014
Risk assessment Overall process comprising a risk analysis and a risk evaluation. ISO 51:2014
Risk evaluation Procedure based on the risk analysis to determine whether tolerable risk has been exceeded. ISO 51:2014
Uncertainty budget Statement of a measurement uncertainty, of the components of that measurement uncertainty, and of their calculation and combination. JCGM 200:2012

question.help: Provide a meaningful name for the dataset(s). The name will also serve as a title for the **Data Quality Assurance Plan**.
question.text: Q01 Dataset label *

attribute.dc:comment: Short ID for a dataset, used as questionset attribute for dataset related questionsets.

question.help: Give general information about the project. Describe what the dataset is, what its purpose is, where it is stored (e.g., link to a data dictionary), where the projectâ€™s documentation is stored etc.
question.text: Q02 Brief description *

page.title: Responsibilities in the data lifecycle
page.help: A Data Quality Assurance Plan is established by the dataset development team. Team members may have different roles: data manager(s), data administrator(s), data technician(s) and data steward(s). These roles are defined by the [ISO 8000](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui#d7868633e259) series of standards. The most essential roles are **data technician** and **data steward**. Smaller development teams might be composed of a small number of **data technicians** and/or **data stewards**. For example, a team might have a single member, who creates (as **data technician**) and manages (as **data steward**) the dataset.

question.text: Q03 Data managers

attribute.dc:comment: Data managers for Mathmet Data Quality.

question.text: Q04 Data administrators
Q05 Data stewards
Q06 Data technicians

page.title: About the data quality management plan
page.help: Provide information about the **Data Quality Assurance Plan** itself: the current status of the plan, still a draft or issued, the latest date when the plan underwent significant changes, and an identifier for the current version of the plan.

question.text: Q07 Data quality management plan status
Q08a Data quality management plan date
Q08b Data quality management plan version

page.title: Calculation of the data integrity level

question.help:
Evaluate the anticipated complexity of the dataset(s). Dataset complexity (CP) can be defined considering (a) the size of the dataset(s), (b) the amount of effort needed for dataset consolidation, and (c) the degree of self-explainingness of the dataset.
Table 1: Data complexity levels, typical features, and examples.
CodeDescriptive nameTypical featuresExample
CP 1Very simple
  • Commonly used datatypes (e.g. numeric).
  • Few datatypes.
  • Small amount of data.
  • Simple/unexpensive capture/generation/processing/storage infrastructure.
  • Simple uncertainty budget.
 Hourly time series of a single room temperature sensor readings over one month.
CP 2Simple
  • Easy to represent visually (e.g. numeric matrix).
  • Moderate number of datatypes.
  • Moderate amount of data.
  • Intermediate capture/generation/processing/storage infrastructure.
  • Intermediate uncertainty budget.
 Hourly time series of room temperature, relative humidity and CO2 concentration sensor readings of a large building over one year.
CP 3Moderate
  • Non-trivial datatypes.
  • Fair number of datatypes.
  • Large or very large datasets.
  • Complex/expensive capture/generation/processing/storage infrastructure.
  • Complicated uncertainty budget.
 Combined thermographic, photogrammetric and 3D point cloud data of a large building.
CP 4Complex
  • Non-trivial datatypes.
  • Combination of many datatypes.
  • Very complex/expensive capture/generation/processing/storage infrastructure.
  • Very complicated uncertainty budget.
 Multi-spectral satellite imagery of a continent.
question.text: Q09 Dataset level of complexity *

question.help:
Evaluate the expected criticality of usage (CU) for the product dataset(s), i.e. An estimate of the consequences (e.g. on business, reputation, life, environment, heritage) arising from usage of data of inappropriate quality or from wrong usage of the dataset.
Table 2: Data criticality levels, explanations, and examples.
CodeDescriptive nameExplanationExample
CU 1Not critical No danger of loss of income or reputation.
Short life, will not require maintenance in future.		 Prototype dataset for internal use.
CU 2Significant Potential for loss of income or reputation. Dataset used for scientific research.
CU 3Substantial Likely to lead to loss of income or reputation if faulty. Dataset used for commercial applications.
CU 4Life critical May result in personal injury or loss of life. Avionics reference standards.
question.text: Q10 Dataset level of criticality *

question.help:
The DIL can be calculated with the following formula: ``` if(CU==1) DIL=1 else DIL=max(CU, CP) ``` This recommended DIL can be accepted, or it could be revised by the team. For example, if inexperienced **data technicians** are involved, the team can decide to increase the DIL. If the DIL value is revised, then the project-specific factors that justify increasing or decreasing the recommended DIL value must be documented.
Table 3: Calculating Data Integrity Level.
CP 1CP 2CP 3CP 4
CU 1DIL 1DIL 1DIL 1DIL 1
CU 2DIL 2DIL 2DIL 3DIL 4
CU 3DIL 3DIL 3DIL 3DIL 4
CU 4DIL 4DIL 4DIL 4DIL 4
question.text: Q11a Does the calculated DIL seem suitable? *
Q11b Factors that justify increasing or decreasing the DIL:
Q11c Amended DIL: *

page.title: Procedures for documentation of the user requirements

question.help: Document user requirements (data specification) in any case, regardless of the DIL value. However, it is expected that higher DIL levels have more detailed user requirements. For example, datasets with higher levels of complexity might have longer mathematical specifications. From Q12, all answer fields support rich and long text, however good practice is to provide a short explanation and a link to a working document (stored in a persistent accessible location).
question.text: Q12 How will the dataset user requirements be documented? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 12
Added for the question which documentation will be available together with the data

question.help: Document the data life cycle: from creation to long-term preservation. For example, provide a short explanation and link to a flow diagram, or for a more complex project, link a Gantt chart, a task board etc. **Data life cycle processes** can include how data is captured (how it is discovered, acquired, recombined from static or dynamic sources), how it is created (data pipeline, if it is synthetic data), how it is formatted (and what format conversions have been applied), how it is annotated (are there metadata?), how it is validated (detection/mitigation of abnormalities is also covered by the data quality monitoring section of the plan), how it is anonymised (for privacy purposes), how the data will be preserved (e.g., is there a retention period?) etc.
question.text: Q13 How will the data life cycle be documented? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 13

question.help: Document the data life cycle: from creation to long-term preservation. For example, provide a short explanation and link to a flow diagram, or for a more complex project, link a Gantt chart, a task board etc. **Data life cycle processes** can include how data is captured (how it is discovered, acquired, recombined from static or dynamic sources), how it is created (data pipeline, if it is synthetic data), how it is formatted (and what format conversions have been applied), how it is annotated (are there metadata?), how it is validated (detection/mitigation of abnormalities is also covered by the data quality monitoring section of the plan), how it is anonymised (for privacy purposes), how the data will be preserved (e.g., is there a retention period?) etc.
question.text: Q13 How will the data life cycle be documented?

question.help: Describe the procedure for approval of the user requirements within the development team. Who oversees collating user requirements? Who approves them within the team? How is the approval traced (email thread, merge request if using a version control system, digital signature, meeting minutesâ€¦)?
question.text: Q14 How will the project team approve the dataset user requirements internally? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 14

question.help: Describe the procedure for approval of the user requirements within the development team. Who oversees collating user requirements? Who approves them within the team? How is the approval traced (email thread, merge request if using a version control system, digital signature, meeting minutesâ€¦)?
question.text: Q14 How will the project team approve the dataset user requirements internally?

question.help: Who is the customer? Who is the **customer** proxy, if any? Describe the procedure for approval by the **customer**. How is user requirement documentation communicated to the **customer**? How is the approval traced (email thread, merge request, digital signature, meeting minutesâ€¦)? If the **customer** is not involved in this procedure, which team members act as a proxy?
question.text: Q15 How will the customer or customer proxy approve the dataset user requirements? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 15

question.help: Who is the customer? Who is the **customer** proxy, if any? Describe the procedure for approval by the **customer**. How is user requirement documentation communicated to the **customer**? How is the approval traced (email thread, merge request, digital signature, meeting minutesâ€¦)? If the **customer** is not involved in this procedure, which team members act as a proxy?
question.text: Q15 How will the customer or customer proxy approve the dataset user requirements?

question.help: Describe how an independent person/organisation will review the user requirements. Depending on the criticality of usage of the dataset, it could be someone in the same organisation with expertise but not directly involved in the development, or an external assessor with an accepted level of authoritativeness/accreditation.
question.text: Q16 How will the objectivity of the dataset user requirements review be ensured? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 16

question.help: Detail the roadmap for the implementation of the data quality interventions, for example by providing a link to a document: a flow diagram (for example, a sub-diagram of the data life cycle diagram) or for more complex projects: Gantt chart, task boardâ€¦ It could also be a link to an external platform, e.g., a project tracker.
question.text: Q17 Describe how the roadmap of data quality procedures will be documented.

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 17

question.help: Detail the roadmap for the implementation of the data quality interventions, for example by providing a link to a document: a flow diagram (for example, a sub-diagram of the data life cycle diagram) or for more complex projects: Gantt chart, task boardâ€¦ It could also be a link to an external platform, e.g., a project tracker.

question.help: Describe the procedure that will be implemented to track progress against the roadmap. For example, progress review meetings with minutes, or approval procedure in a project tracker.

question.help: Document the risk assessment associated to the development of the dataset. What could go wrong and how to mitigate? For examples, having redundant instruments, setting up data backup procedures.
question.text: Q19 How will the risks associated to developing the dataset be assessed and mitigated? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 19

question.help: Describe how non-conformities are identified and documented. Internal reporting and customer reporting could have different channels. For example, the development team can set up a procedure to assign priority levels to non-conformities. ISO 8000 standards characterise data quality according to its consistency with its format (syntactic quality), its meaning (semantic quality), and its usefulness (pragmatic quality).
question.text: Q21 How will non-conformities in the dataset be reported? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 21

question.help: Describe how non-conformities are identified and documented. Internal reporting and customer reporting could have different channels. ISO 8000 standards characterise data quality according to its consistency with its format (syntactic quality), its meaning (semantic quality), and its usefulness (pragmatic quality).

question.help: Describe how the processes for review and mitigation of data quality issues will be reviewed independently. Depending on the criticality level, the independent reviewer can be someone in the same organisation who is not involved in the development of the dataset, or an external expert.
question.text: Q28 How will the objectivity of the data quality issue review be ensured? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 28

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 25

question.help: Provide a link to a document (for example, a shared Word document in review mode), or a link to a dedicated platform (for example, an issue tracker).
question.text: Q25 How will data quality be documented and made available for review?

question.help: Provide, for example, a link to an agenda for review meetings with minutes, or a link to a chat history that is private to the team.
question.text: Q26 How will the project team review data quality issues?

question.help: Provide a link to a data specification document. A machine-interpretable format specification must be provided if compliance with the [FAIR principles](https://www.go-fair.org/fair-principles/) is desired, e.g., the dataset is intended to be shared in an open science data repository.
question.text: Q29 How will the meaning of the data be formalised? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 29

question.help: Provide a link to a data specification document. A machine-interpretable format specification must be provided if compliance with the [FAIR principles](https://www.go-fair.org/fair-principles/) is desired, e.g., the dataset is intended to be shared in an open science data repository.
question.text: Q29 How will the meaning of the data be formalised?

question.help: Provide a link to a data model document/diagram (e.g., a UML diagram), or a database schema with metadata (e.g., the dataset is kept in a relational database). A machine-interpretable format specification needs to be provided to comply with the [FAIR principles](https://www.go-fair.org/fair-principles/).
question.text: Q30 How will the structure of the dataset be documented?

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 30

question.help: Provide a link to metadata database schema, a controlled vocabulary, a taxonomyâ€¦ In simpler cases, a README file that explains the headers, if the data is shared in a tabular format. A machine-interpretable format specification needs to be provided to comply with the [FAIR principles](https://www.go-fair.org/fair-principles/).
question.text: Q31 How will the metadata be documented?

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 31

question.help: Detail how customers will learn about the dataset usage. For example, provide a link to a user manual in PDF format, or a link to a documentation wiki/web site. For more complex datasets/intended usage, describe how training will be provided, e.g., online or via in-person workshops/classesâ€¦
question.text: Q32 How will the customer know how to exploit the dataset? *

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 32

question.help: Detail how customers will learn about the dataset usage. For example, provide a link to a user manual in PDF format, or a link to a documentation wiki/web site. For more complex datasets/intended usage, describe how training will be provided, e.g., online or via in-person workshops/classesâ€¦
question.text: Q32 How will the customer know how to exploit the dataset?

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 33

question.text: Q34 How will the main operations applied to the dataset be logged? *

question.help: If the dataset contains measurement data, describe the logging procedure for the main operation, e.g., by providing a link to a document/diagram.
question.text: Q34 How will the main operations applied to the dataset be logged?

question.help: For higher levels of criticality/complexity, describe all operations performed on or in relation to the dataset, e.g., provide a processing pipeline specification.

question.help: For higher levels of criticality/complexity, describe all operations performed on or in relation to the dataset, e.g., provide a processing pipeline specification.
question.text: Q35 How will the operations applied to the dataset be logged?

question.help: â€œMeasurement dataâ€ here refers to values obtained experimentally, either by comparison of quantities with reference quantities or units or counting of entities, as well as values derived from experimental results using models and calculations.
question.text: Q33 Will the dataset contain measurement data or data derived from measurements? *

question.help: Repeatability is defined as: _Condition of measurement, out of a set of conditions that includes **the same** measurement procedure, **same** operators, **same** measuring system, **same** operating conditions and **same location**, and replicate measurements on the same or similar objects **over a short period of time**._ (Source: [International Vocabulary of Metrology (VIM)](https://doi.org/10.59161/JCGM200-2012))
question.text: Q36 Is the dataset generation intended to be repeatable?

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 36

question.help: Detail how repeatability conditions are documented. For example, provide a link to a document which details how to find the persons, locations, artifacts, instruments, and procedures involved in any repeated experiment.
question.text: Q37 How will the datasetâ€™s repeatability conditions be documented?

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 37

question.help: Reproducibility: _Condition of measurement, out of a set of conditions that includes **different** locations, operators, measuring systems, and replicate measurements on the same or similar objects._ (Source: [International Vocabulary of Metrology (VIM)](https://doi.org/10.59161/JCGM200-2012))
question.text: Q38 Is the dataset generation intended to be reproducible?
Q39 How will the datasetâ€™s reproducibility conditions be documented?

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 39

question.help: Repeatability: _Condition of measurement, out of a set of conditions that includes **the same** measurement procedure, **same** operators, **same** measuring system, **same** operating conditions and **same location**, and replicate measurements on the same or similar objects **over a short period of time**._ (Source: [International Vocabulary of Metrology (VIM)](https://doi.org/10.59161/JCGM200-2012))
question.text: Q36 Is the dataset generation intended to be repeatable? *
Q37 How will the datasetâ€™s repeatability conditions be documented? *

question.help: Reproducibility is defined as: _Condition of measurement, out of a set of conditions that includes **different** locations, operators, measuring systems, and replicate measurements on the same or similar objects._ (Source: [International Vocabulary of Metrology (VIM)](https://doi.org/10.59161/JCGM200-2012))
question.text: Q38 Is the dataset generation intended to be reproducible? *

question.help: Detail how reproducibility conditions are documented. For example, provide a link to a document that describes the persons, locations, artifacts, instruments, and procedures involved in the original experiment and the degree of similitude expected from any reproduction.
question.text: Q39 How will the datasetâ€™s reproducibility conditions be documented? *

question.help:
Document how **measurement uncertainty** is expressed/evaluated. Refer to the [Guide to the expression of uncertainty in measurement (GUM)](https://doi.org/ 10.59161/JCGM100-2008E) when possible, or provide links to explanatory documents (reports, papers) when the uncertainty evaluation is not traceable to the GUM. If there is an uncertainty budget, provide a link and explain how it is traceable to the GUM, if not, justify why there isn't one.
If the evaluation is performed using commercial software: specify the tools and version used. If it is performed using in-house software, specify tools and version used, and link to the source code and/or a software quality plan.
question.text: Q40 How will measurement uncertainty be expressed and evaluated?

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 40

question.help: For higher levels of criticality of usage, this could be a link to a recent accreditation certificate conform to the [ISO/IEC 17025 "General requirements for the competence of testing and calibration laboratories"](https://www.iso.org/standard/66912.html).
question.text: Q41 How will confidence in the dataset generation process be demonstrated?

attribute.dc:comment: Created for Mathmet Data Quality Assurance Plan, Question 41
